question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & 0 \\
x & - & 2y & - & z & + & 2t & = & 1 \\
x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & 0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,0,\,1+y\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(0,\,0,\,0,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(0,\,y,\,0,\,z\right)$ as solutions for every $y,z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 3y & + & 6z & = & a \\ 
3x & + & y & + & 3z & = & 1 \\ 
6x & + & 6y & + & z & = & 1 \\
7x & + & 9y & + & 7z & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions for $b\neq a+1$. 

If $b=a+1$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{37-14a}{100},\,\frac{3a-4}{20},\,\frac{1+3a}{25}\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer2: The system has no solution for every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
If $b\neq a+1$, the system has no solutions. 

Otherwise, for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{3+3a-z}{2},\,\frac{2+a-2z}{2},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
If $b=a+1$ the system has no solution. 

Otherwise, for every $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{a+b+1}{20},\,\frac{-a-b+2}{3},\,\frac{2a+3b-4}{15}\right)$.

answer3: If $T:\mathbb{R}^2\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is a linear transformation, then $T$ can be a sobrejection.
answer4: If $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is a linear transformation and $ker(T)\neq \left\{(0,0,0\right\}$, then $T$ can be a sobrejection.

The authorities of the city want to predict the price $y$ of a house, depending on its environment. The environment value $x$ is estimated by a special complex index. In this situation, identify the correct interpretation of the coefficients in the fitted regression line $\hat{y} = 200000+30000x$.
answer1: The slope is equal to $30 000$ and implies that for every unit increase in the environment index the mean value of the house price is estimated to increase by $30 000$ units.
answer2: The slope of $30 000$ implies that for every unit increase in house price, the mean value of the environment index is estimated to increase by $30 000$ units.
answer3: The y-intercept implies that the estimated mean price of a house is equal to $30 000$ units when the index of the environment is equal to $0$ units.

Consider the vectors $u=(1, 3, 2)$, $v=(-1, 1, 2)$ and $w=(0, 1, 1)$ of $\mathbb{R}^3$ and the scalar triple product $u\cdot (v\times w)$. 
Choose the correct answer.
answer1: $u\cdot (v\times w) = 0$ and the vector $v \times w$ is normal to the vector $u$.
answer2: $u\cdot (v\times w) = (-1, 1, 1)$ and $u \times v$ and $w$ are coplanar vectors.
answer3: $u\cdot (v\times w) = 0$ and $u \times v$ and $w$ are coplanar vectors.
answer4: $u\cdot (v\times w) = 1$ and the vector $v \times w$ is normal to vector $u$.

question: Find the flux of $\displaystyle\textbf{F}$ across S, where $\displaystyle\textbf{F}(x,y,z)=x\textbf{i}+y\textbf{j}+5\textbf{k}\,$, where S is the boundary of the region enclosed by the cylinder $\displaystyle x^2+z^2=1\,$ and the planes $\displaystyle y=0\,$ and $\displaystyle x+y=2$.

$$\begin{cases}
&2x &- &y &+ &3z &= &8 \\
&-3x &+ &2y &+ &z &= &-7 \\
&-2x &+ &y &+ &2z &= &-3
\end{cases}$$

Consider the usual scalar product of the vectors $u=(-1, 2, 1)$ and $v=(3, -6, -3)$ of $\mathbb{R}^3$. 
Choose the right answer:
answer1: The vectors $u$ and $v$ are collinear and the magnitude of $u$ is $\sqrt{6}$.
answer2: The set $\{ u, v\}$ is orthogonal and the magnitude of $u$ is $\sqrt{6}$.
answer3: The vectors $u$ and $v$ are collinear and the magnitude of $u$ is $6$.
answer4: The set $\{ u, v\}$ is orthogonal and the magnitude of $u$ is $6$.

Find the integral curve which satisfies the equation $x+xx'=tx-x'$ with initial condition $x(2)=1$.
answer1: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $t-\frac{1}{2}t^{2}+x+\ln|x|=1$.
answer2: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $t-\frac{1}{2}t^{2}+x+\ln|x|=0$.
answer3: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $t-t^{2}+x+\ln|x|=1$.
answer4: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $t+\frac{1}{2}t^{2}+x-\ln|x|=0$.
